731601f-a.text:
(1)
Feast of Our Lady of Mt. Carmel; 1924; No. 19: Fhotographers, standing on 114th Street near Pleasant Avenue, Jefferson
Park in the background.
July 16, 1924.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.  45G0  E
(2)
No. 2O. Lemonade vender, Fleasant Avenue, east side, between
114th and 115th Streets.
July 16, 1924.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
No. 21. A fortune teller with a parrot and two trained white
mice, location uncertain.
July 16, 1924.
P. L. Sperr.

731611f-b.title: Feast of Our Lady of Mount Carmel.
731611f-b.text:
(1)
Feast of Our Lady of Mt. Carmel: Vendors of clams, with pushcart set up in Jefferson Park, at 114th Street and Pleasant Avenue. In the background is seen part of the Standard Gas Light plant
which in a few years is to be demolished.
July 16, 1926.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
Vendors of sacred pictures, rosaries, and other religious trinkets, on Pleasant Avenue; the view is north from 114th
Street.
July 16, 1926.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
Votive images, dolls and candles on sale, shop near Jeffenson
Park.
July 16, 1926.
P. L. Sperr.
731611f-b.folder: 114th Street and Pleasant Avenue  , Manhattan, N.Y.

731617f-b.title: Feast of Our Lady of Mount Carmel.
731617f-b.text:
(1)

Feast of Our Lady of Mt. Carmel: Meat being broiled over charcoal, at a stand on 114th Street opposite the N.W. corner of Pleasant Avenue.
Part of the Standard Gas Light plant, which in a few years will be demolished, is shown in the background.

July 16, 1929

P.L. Sperr
NO REPRODUCTIONS                 NEG. #4972

(2)

Later in the day this watermelon stand was set up on the N.W. corner of Pleasant Avenue and 114th Street.  This is the same corner which is shown in the above view.

July 16, 1929

P.L. Sperr
NO REPRODUCTIONS
731617f-b.folder: 114th Street and Pleasant Avenue, Manhattan, N.Y.

722626f-a.text:
Pleasant Ave., east side, north fro and including East 114th to and including 115th Streets. This, the Standard Gas Light Co. Plant, will
be completeydemolished.
September 12, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.

722628f-a.text:
(1)
A rear view of Pleasant Ave., east side, from, but not including East 114th to and including 115th Streets. The view shows a portion of the site of the Standard Gas Light Co., Plant, during demolition. Gas tanks shown, are on the S.E. corner of East 115th Street.
September 12, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, from a different angle. Notice the spire of the Church oof Our Lady of Mt. Carmel, (on East 115th Street, west of Pleasant Ave),
through the structural frame of gas tanks.
November 9, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.

722628f-b.text:
(1)
A rear view of Pleasant Ave., east side, from, but not including East 114th to and including 115th Streets. The view shows a portion of the site of the Standard Gas Light Co., Plant, during demolition. Gas tanks shown, are on the S.E. corner of East 115th Street.
September 12, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, from a different angle. Notice the spire of the Church oof Our Lady of Mt. Carmel, (on East 115th Street, west of Pleasant Ave),
through the structural frame of gas tanks.
November 9, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.

722627f-a.text:
(1) Pleasant Avenue, West side, from 114th to 115th Streets, seen from 115th Street near the Harlem River; the view is west on 115th Street.  In consequence of the demolition of the Standard Gas Light Company's plant and tanks on either side of 115th Street; it is possible to see a little of Jefferson Park and a few houses on First Avenue, south of 114th Street, shown at the left, also the rear of the buildings on the east side of Pleasant Avenue south of 445th Street, shown at the right

July 19, 1935
P.L.Sperr,
NC REPRODUCTIONS

(2) Pleasant Avenue, West side, from 114th to 115th Streets, a close view, not showing the full corner of 115th Street.
Pleasant Avenue is part of Avenue A, as originally surveyed.
It extends from 107th to 124th Streets, and has been known under its present name since the 1870s.  Jefferson Park was laid out around 1900, breaking Pleasant Avenue between 111th and 114th Streets.

July 19, 1935
P.L.Sperr,
NC REPRODUCTIONS

722627f-b.text:
(1) Pleasant Avenue, West side, from 114th to 115th Streets, seen from 115th Street near the Harlem River; the view is west on 115th Street.  In consequence of the demolition of the Standard Gas Light Company's plant and tanks on either side of 115th Street; it is possible to see a little of Jefferson Park and a few houses on First Avenue, south of 114th Street, shown at the left, also the rear of the buildings on the east side of Pleasant Avenue south of 445th Street, shown at the right

July 19, 1935
P.L.Sperr,
NC REPRODUCTIONS

(2) Pleasant Avenue, West side, from 114th to 115th Streets, a close view, not showing the full corner of 115th Street.
Pleasant Avenue is part of Avenue A, as originally surveyed.
It extends from 107th to 124th Streets, and has been known under its present name since the 1870s.  Jefferson Park was laid out around 1900, breaking Pleasant Avenue between 111th and 114th Streets.

July 19, 1935
P.L.Sperr,
NC REPRODUCTIONS

731643f-b.title: Feast of Our Lady of Mount Carmel.
731643f-b.text:
(1)

Feast of Our Lady of Mt. Carmel: Pretnels for sale by two enterprising youngsters at the eastern end of 114th Street, east of Pleasant Avenue.
The sign in the background applies to the ferris wheel, which is not shown in this view.

July 16, 1935.
P.L.Sperr
NO REPRODUCTIONS

(2)

Another pretnel vendor, at the S.E. corner of Pleasant Avenue and 114th Street. The view is east. Notice the ferris wheel, operated by the American Legion, in the background.

July 16, 1935
P.L.Sperr
NO REROUUCTIONS
NEG #4017

(3)

Pretnels, on the S.E. corner of First Avenue and 114th Street.
The view is roughly northwest.

July 16. 1935

P.L. Sperr
NO REPRODUCTIONS

The same street at First Ave.

722629f-b.text:
Pleasant Avenue, east side, between East 114th and 116th Streets, showing the new site for the Benjamin Franklin High School under preparation. This S3,500,000 structure is to seat 3285 students. It will be erected in the form of a double E and front onto the East River Drive. A fuller account of the various details and an architects sketch will be found in the New York
Times of November 22, 1939.
Individually the photographer gives the locations as, northward from the new East River Drive and 114th Street in No. 1: a demolition at Pleasant Avenue and 115th Street in No. 2; and another demolition at the S. E. corner of 116th Street and the Avenue, in
No. 3.
July 16, 1939
Views 1,2,3
P. L. Sperr

November 9, 1934.

722625f-a.text:
Pleasant Ave., west side, north from, but not including East 114th Street. as seen across on the N.E. corner of East 114th Street.

722630f-a.text:

March 6, 1936.
